003 * image processing published by Springer-Verlag in various languages and editions.

006 * Copyright (c) 2006-2022 Wilhelm Burger, Mark J. Burge. 
007 * All rights reserved. Visit https://imagingbook.com for additional details.
008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.util;
010
011import java.util.stream.IntStream;
012
013/**
014 * <p>
015 * Determines the 'permutation' of a sequence of numbers and keeps it as an
016 * array ({@link #perm}) of position indexes. These indexes indicate how the
017 * original input array may be re-ordered to become sorted (see
018 * {@link #getPermutation()}).
019 * </p>
020 * <p>
021 * Usage example - get the second-smallest element of a {@code double} array:
022 * </p>
023 * <pre>
024 * double[] a = ...     // some array
025 * int k = SortMap.getNthSmallestIndex(a, 1);   // index of second-smallest element
026 * double x = a[k];
027 * </pre>
028 * <p>
029 * Alternatively,
030 * </p>
031 * <pre>
032 * double x = getNthSmallestValue(a, 1);
033 * </pre>
034 * 
035 * @author WB
036 * @version 2022/09/15
037 */
038public class SortMap {
039        
040        private final int[] perm;
041        
042        /**
043         * Constructor for {@code double[]}. The input array is not modified.
044         * @param numbers the input array
045         */
046        public SortMap(double[] numbers) {
047                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
048                        .sorted((i, j) -> Double.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
049                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
050        }
051        
052        /**
053         * Constructor for {@code float[]}. The input array is not modified.
054         * @param numbers the input array
055         */
056        public SortMap(float[] numbers) {
057                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
058                        .sorted((i, j) -> Float.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
059                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
060        }
061        
062        /**
063         * Constructor for {@code int[]}. The input array is not modified.
064         * @param numbers the input array
065         */
066        public SortMap(int[] numbers) {
067                this.perm = IntStream.range(0, numbers.length).boxed()
068                        .sorted((i, j) -> Integer.compare(numbers[i], numbers[j]))
069                        .mapToInt(x->x.intValue()).toArray();
070        }
071        
072        // --------------------------------------------------
073        
074        /**
075         * Returns the permutation (position indexes) for the underlying
076         * number sequence as a {@code int} array.
077         * That is, the first value in the returned array is the index
078         * of the smallest element in {@code numbers}, the second element
079         * points to the second-smallest element, etc.
080         * For example, if the original number sequence (passed to the constructor) is
081         * <pre>
082         * double[] a = {50.0, 20.0, 100.0, 120.0, 40.0, -10.0};</pre>
083         * then the index array produced by 
084         * <pre>int[] perm = new SortMap(a).getPermutation();</pre> contains
085         * {@code (5, 1, 4, 0, 2, 3)}.
086         * This means that 
087         * <pre>a[perm[i]] &le; a[perm[i+1]]</pre>
088         * and thus the sequence
089         * <pre>{a[perm[0]], A[perm[1]],..., A[perm[N-1]]}</pre>
090         * is sorted.
091         * 
092         * @return the sorting map (permutation)
093         */
094        public int[] getPermutation() {
095                return this.perm;
096        }
097        
098        /**
099         * Returns the index of the n-th smallest element of the original number sequence
100         * (passed to the constructor),
101         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the index of the smallest element.
102         * 
103         * @param n the index
104         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element in the original number sequence
105         */
106        public int getIndex(int n) {
107                if (n < 0 || n >= perm.length) {
108                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("position index n out of range: " + n);
109                }
110                return perm[n];
111        }
112        
113        // --------------------------------------------------
114        
115        /**
116         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified array,
117         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest 
118         * element of the array.
119         * 
120         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
121         * @param n the index
122         * @return the n-th smallest element
123         */
124        public static double getNthSmallestValue(double[] numbers, int n) {
125                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
126        }
127        
128        /**
129         * Returns the index of the nth smallest element of the specified array,
130         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
131         * the array.
132         * 
133         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
134         * @param n the index
135         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element
136         */
137        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(double[] numbers, int n) {
138                return new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
139        }
140        
141        /**
142         * Returns the largest element of the specified array.
143         * 
144         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
145         * @return the largest element
146         */
147        public static double getLargestValue(double[] numbers) {
148                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
149        }
150        
151        /**
152         * Returns the index of the largest element of the specified array.
153         * 
154         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
155         * @return the index of the largest element
156         */
157        public static int getLargestIndex(double[] numbers) {
158                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
159        }
160        
161        /**
162         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified array,
163         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
164         * the array.
165         * 
166         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
167         * @param n the index
168         * @return the n-th smallest element
169         */
170        public static float getNthSmallestValue(float[] numbers, int n) {
171                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
172        }
173        
174        /**
175         * Returns the index of the nth smallest element of the specified array,
176         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
177         * the array.
178         * 
179         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
180         * @param n the index
181         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element
182         */
183        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(float[] numbers, int n) {
184                return new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
185        }
186        
187        /**
188         * Returns the largest element of the specified array.
189         * 
190         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
191         * @return the largest element
192         */
193        public static float getLargestValue(float[] numbers) {
194                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
195        }
196        
197        /**
198         * Returns the index of the largest element of the specified array.
199         * 
200         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
201         * @return the index of the largest element
202         */
203        public static int getLargestIndex(float[] numbers) {
204                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
205        }
206        
207        /**
208         * Returns the nth smallest element of the specified {@code int[]},
209         * starting with {@code n = 0}, which returns the smallest element of {@code numbers}.
210         * 
211         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
212         * @param n the index
213         * @return the n-th smallest element of {@code numbers}
214         */
215        public static int getNthSmallestValue(int[] numbers, int n) {
216                return numbers[getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, n)];
217        }
218        
219        /**
220         * Returns the index of the nth smallest element of the specified array,
221         * starting with n = 0, which returns the smallest element of 
222         * the array.
223         * 
224         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
225         * @param n the index
226         * @return the index of the n-th smallest element
227         */
228        public static int getNthSmallestIndex(int[] numbers, int n) {
229                return new SortMap(numbers).getIndex(n);
230        }
231        
232        /**
233         * Returns the largest element of the specified array.
234         * 
235         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
236         * @return the largest element
237         */
238        public static float getLargestValue(int[] numbers) {
239                return numbers[getLargestIndex(numbers)];
240        }
241        
242        /**
243         * Returns the index of the largest element of the specified array.
244         * 
245         * @param numbers sequence of unsorted values
246         * @return the index of the largest element
247         */
248        public static int getLargestIndex(int[] numbers) {
249                return getNthSmallestIndex(numbers, numbers.length - 1);
250        }
251        
252}
